monteCarlo.title: Monte Carlo Strategy Simulator
monteCarlo.subtitle: Stress-test your trading strategy with statistical simulations

dataSource.title: Data Source

params.title: Simulation Parameters

metrics.kellyDescription: Helps you decide how much to risk per trade based on your win rate and reward/risk ratio.

v2.title: Capital Expectancy Simulator
v2.subtitle: Day-aware Monte Carlo simulation respecting your decision tree
v2.capitalExplanation: This simulation applies your risk management profile's position sizing (compression cycle) to show expected dollar returns. Your profile's risk decay model determines how edge converts into capital growth.

params.budgetExceeded: Budget exceeded. Reduce simulations, trading days, or months.

analysis.title: Trading Strategy Analysis
analysis.mostLikelyOutcome: This is your most likely outcome
analysis.simulationsProfitable: {percent}% of all simulations were profitable, indicating {quality}.
analysis.profitQualityRisky: a risky strategy that needs improvement
analysis.reliableStrategy: A reliable strategy should be profitable in at least 70% of simulations.
analysis.commissionCostsNegligible: Commission costs are negligible relative to your edge.
analysis.commissionCostsModerate: Commission costs are moderate — consider negotiating lower rates.
analysis.commissionCostsHigh: Commission costs significantly erode your edge.
analysis.bestStrategyTip: The best strategy is one you can execute consistently with confidence.

tooltips.sharpeRatio: Measures risk-adjusted return by comparing average return to its volatility. Above 1.0 = good, above 2.0 = excellent. Below 0.5 suggests returns don't justify the risk taken.
tooltips.sortinoRatio: Like Sharpe but only penalizes downside volatility (losses), ignoring upside variance. Above 1.0 = good, above 2.0 = strong. Better than Sharpe for strategies with asymmetric returns.
tooltips.kellyCriterion: Mathematical formula that calculates the optimal fraction of capital to risk per trade to maximize long-term growth. Full Kelly is aggressive — most traders use Half or Quarter Kelly for smoother equity curves.
tooltips.kellyQuarter: Conservative: 25% of Full Kelly. Slower growth but much smoother equity curve. Best for risk-averse traders or unproven strategies.
tooltips.kellyHalf: Balanced: 50% of Full Kelly. Good trade-off between growth and drawdown control. Most commonly recommended for experienced traders.
tooltips.kellyFull: Aggressive: Maximum growth rate but with severe drawdowns. Mathematically optimal but psychologically difficult. Rarely used in practice.
tooltips.profitFactor: Total winning R divided by total losing R. Above 1.0 = profitable. Above 1.5 = solid edge. Above 2.0 = strong system. Below 1.0 means the system loses money overall.
tooltips.expectedRPerTrade: Your mathematical edge per trade in R-multiples. Positive = profitable system. Example: +0.3R means you gain 0.3 units of risk per trade on average over many trades.
tooltips.maxDrawdown: Largest peak-to-trough decline in R-multiples. Measures worst-case pain. Lower is better. A 5R drawdown means losing 5x your risk unit from peak before recovering.
tooltips.profitableSimulations: Percentage of Monte Carlo runs ending in profit. Above 80% = robust edge. 60-80% = moderate confidence. Below 60% = strategy may not be reliable.
tooltips.profitableMonths: Percentage of simulated months ending positive. Above 70% = consistent. 50-70% = moderate. Below 50% suggests frequent losing months.
tooltips.monthlyLimitHit: How often the monthly loss limit was triggered. Below 10% = well-managed risk. Above 20% = strategy frequently hits safety stops.
tooltips.expectedDailyPnl: Average daily profit/loss across all simulations. Accounts for position sizing, commission costs, and the compression cycle from your risk profile.
tooltips.riskOfRuin: Percentage of simulations where balance dropped to or below the ruin threshold. Lower is better.
tooltips.ruinThreshold: Account loss percentage that constitutes 'ruin'. E.g., 50% means ruin if balance drops to half of starting capital.

analytics.title: Analytics
analytics.description: Analyze your performance and identify patterns
analytics.expectancyTooltipR: Edge Expectancy — measures strategy quality in R-multiples. Account-size independent: 1R is 1R whether your account is $10K or $1M. Use this to evaluate your trading edge objectively.
analytics.expectancyTooltipCapital: Capital Expectancy — shows actual dollar P&L impact. Depends on position sizing: same edge produces different $ results at different risk levels.
analytics.expectancyTooltipDiffer: A strategy with great R performance but small position sizes will look strong in R but modest in $. Large positions amplify $ results even with a mediocre R edge.

tableTooltips.pnl: Net Profit & Loss (total gains minus losses)

tableTooltips.avgR: Average R-multiple per trade (actual return ÷ planned risk)
tableTooltips.pf: Profit Factor (sum of wins ÷ sum of losses)
